metadata.case_name: Munshi Ram v. Faqir Chand and Banwarilal

facts.text: Munshi Ram was adopted by Mangalsain when five or six years old. Mangalsain was separate from other branch. Firm Kanhaiyalal Sons consisting of Kanhaiyalal and his two sons fell on evil days.
Munshi Ram started concern 'Munshi Ram, B.Sc.' which prospered. Respondents claimed to be partners in that business.
On October 30, 1946, agreement between contesting parties referring dispute to sole arbitration of Lala Premnath, Advocate.

Lala Premnath gave award on March 3, 1947: Rs. 50,000 to Faqir Chand (Rs. 15,000 on April 4, 1947, balance in three equal instalments on August 4, 1947, December 4, 1947, March 4, 1948, interest at 0-8-0% per mensem on default); Rs. 45,000 to Banwarilal similarly; haveli given in moieties to Faqir Chand and Banwarilal; rest immovable property to Munshi Ram as self-acquired; no connection with concern 'Munshi Ram, B.Sc.'; income-tax 1945-46 to be paid equally by three parties when assessed.
On April 4, 1947, Rs. 15,000 paid to Banwarilal.
On request of Faqir Chand on December 17, 1947, arbitrator filed application under s.14(2) Arbitration Act on January 6, 1948 with signed copy of award (original lost).
On February 19, 1948, Stamp Auditor reported deficiency of Rs. 662-8-0 on copy (original on Rs.50 stamp). Recommended impounding.
Senior Sub Judge, Ferozepore ordered report to be considered when document produced.
On July 11, 1948, Munshi Ram applied to set aside award: insufficiently stamped, not registered, arbitrator misconduct, beyond time.
Parties stated prepared to have decree passed per terms accepted by them (further settlement).

By order October 18, 1948, Court passed decree on award modifying terms: Rs.46,000 to Faqir Chand, Rs.41,000 to Banwarilal (deducted Rs.4,000 each for income-tax share); changed instalments; award not operative re haveli.
Objections of Stamp Auditor and others not considered.
On December 27, 1949, Banwarilal applied for execution for defaulted instalment.

On January 3, 1950, Munshi Ram objected under O.47 r.1, ss.47,151 CPC: order making award rule of court after modifying void; original not filed, only copy; insufficient stamp, no deficit/penalty; decree instrument of partition needing stamp.

Senior Sub Judge, Ferozepore by order March 3, 1951: copy admissible (original lost); compromise possible post-award; award/decree instrument of partition, deficient stamp; rejected execution but allowed fresh execution after proper stamp on decree.
Munshi Ram appealed to High Court: Execution First Appeal No.121 of 1951 against rider in March 3 order.
On March 10, 1951, Banwarilal second execution application depositing stamp papers.
Executing Court March 28, 1951 impounded decree, sent to Collector.
Banwarilal appealed: Execution First Appeal No.56 of 1951.
Munshi Ram also appealed against March 28 order (not printed).
Single Judge heard EFA 56/1951 first: Dec 28, 1951 set aside impounding (treated as revision); decree properly stamped after deposit; proceedings ended March 3, 1951; no reopening.
Single Judge June 16, 1952 in EFA 121/1951: appeal incompetent, no revision interference.
Munshi Ram's other appeal against March 28 dismissed (order set aside already).
Munshi Ram filed L.P. Appeals 5 and 11 of 1952; dismissed by common judgment Nov 26, 1952.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court confined to L.P.A. No.11/1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether after an award is filed in court, parties can enter into a compromise modifying the terms of the award, and court can pass decree on award as modified by compromise.
Whether decree passed on basis of unstamped/insufficiently stamped award/copy is nullity and unexecutable.

petitioner_arguments.text: After dispute referred to arbitration and award filed, court cannot record compromise under O.23 r.3 CPC modifying award; award can only be set aside or modified per Arbitration Act; no provision for compromise.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arbitration Act ss.15,30,32; Rabindranath Chakrabarti v. Jnanendra Mohan Bhaduri (1931) I.L.R. 58 Cal. 1018 (approved PC); Dooly Chand Srimali v. Mohan Lal Srimali (1924) I.L.R. 51 Cal. 432; Brindaban Chandra v. Kashi Chandra; Motandas v. Wadhumal AIR 1948 Sind. 74; O.23 r.3 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Original award not filed, only copy; insufficiently stamped without deficit/penalty recovery; decree instrument of partition needing stamp; void, without jurisdiction, nullity.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Stamp Act; s.17 Registration Act implied

respondent_arguments.text: Compromise possible after award; court can pass decree modifying award per compromise.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Dwarka Das v. Krishna Kishore (1921) I.L.R. 2 Lah. 114; Behari Lal v. Dholan Das (1910) 5 IC 994; Attar Singh v. Bishan Singh AIR 1945 Pesh. 41; Fazal Ahmad v. Enayat Ahmad AIR 1922 Oudh. 189; O.23 r.3 CPC

respondent_arguments.text: Copy admissible (original lost); stamp deposited; decree properly stamped post March 10, 1951.

court_reasoning.text: Point not raised before lower courts/High Court; conceded possible per Dwarka Das; only stamping/jurisdiction urged earlier; not in certificate grounds; only in SL petition; decline on this ground alone.
Decree not questioned on this ground at passing (consent); in execution, only nullity executable.

Court can record compromise modifying award and pass decree: Arbitration Act 1940 ss.15 limits court modification, but parties can compromise; s.41 applies CPC (O.23 r.3); if within reference, include in operative decree; else schedule.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act does not disable parties terminating dispute by compromise; follow PC in Hemanta Kumari (award as modified executable).

court_reasoning.text: Here, compromise worked out award's income-tax direction (quantified, reduced amounts); mode of payment altered - within award.
Pre-1940 Act cases inapplicable (award executable per se, no decree power).

holdings.text: After award filed, if parties compromise modifying terms (not throwing overboard), court may pass decree per award as modified, including in operative part if within reference.
Decree here properly framed, not nullity.

precedents_cited.relevance: Compromise possible post-award; decree on modified award.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rabindranath Chakrabarti v. Jnanendra Mohan Bhaduri
Jnanendra Mohan Bhaduri v. Rabindra Nath Chakravarti
Dooly Chand Srimali v. Mohan Lal Srimali

precedents_cited.relevance: Parties can compromise proceedings by altering award.
Act limits court interference, not party withdrawal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prafulla Chandra Karmakar v. Panchanan Karmakar
precedents_cited.relevance: Court can supersede reference on compromise; discussed anomaly.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lala Khunni Lal v. Gobind Krishna Narain
Hemanta Kumari Debi v. Midnapur Zimindari Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Decree can recite/include compromise wholly or in schedule.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Filing award; limited court modification; no bar to party compromise; CPC applies subject to Act.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Record compromise, pass decree; review; execution; inherent powers; procedure.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Stamp Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Deficiency on award/decree as partition instrument; impounding.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed. Held court can pass decree on award modified by post-award compromise of parties if within reference; here compromise quantified income-tax per award and altered payment mode; decree valid, not nullity.

key_quotes.text: "it would seem strange if the law also were that once a reference has been made to arbitration, the parties can no longer even settle their dispute or bring the settlement before the Court, but must continue the strife till a decree on the basis of the award is made"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights anomaly of barring compromise post-reference.

key_quotes.text: "The power to record such an agreement and to make it a part of the decree... will follow from the application of the Code of Civil Procedure, by s.41 of the Arbitration Act and also s.141 of the Code."
key_quotes.speaker: court
